awd_titl_txt: Exploring Strong-Field Gravity through Gravitational-Wave and Multimessenger Observations
awd_abstract_narration:
The overarching goal of this project is to reveal how well one can ultimately probe the nature of strong, dynamical, and nonlinear gravity through gravitational-wave observations of black holes and multimessenger observations of neutron stars. Currently, one of the biggest challenges in testing General Relativity with gravitational waves from binary black hole coalescences is the lack of complete gravitational waveforms from theories beyond General Relativity that are valid throughout the inspiral, merger, and ringdown of the binary evolution. Moreover, for binary neutron stars, certain tests of General Relativity are limited by uncertainties in nuclear matter properties. The PI will tackle these problems by (I) constructing, for the first time, gravitational waveforms in theories beyond General Relativity that are valid in all of the inspiral-merger-ringdown phases, and (II) performing a comprehensive study of multimessenger tests of General Relativity with neutron star observations by avoiding uncertainties in nuclear physics. The gravitational waveform models to be developed will be ready to use and can be widely adopted by the gravitational wave community and beyond. Multimessenger tests of General Relativity with neutron star observations are extremely timely, and the outcome of both projects will impact various communities in physics and beyond, including gravitational physics, particle physics, nuclear physics, and astrophysics. The long-term educational goal of the project is to connect, globally, potential next-generation scientists and convey the beauty and excitement of physics, in particular General Relativity. 

For the construction of the complete gravitational waveforms, the PI will work in a specific gravitational theory motivated by string theory, in which some simulations are already available. The PI and collaborators will produce more simulation data for the merger-ringdown and will stitch them against analytic waveforms during the inspiral. These complete waveforms allow one to probe more precisely theories beyond General Relativity with the existing gravitational wave events and will assist in searches for new physics with future observations. For multi-messenger tests, the PI will employ universal relations among certain neutron star observables that do not depend sensitively on the unknown internal structure of neutron stars. The PI will study such relations in a few theories beyond General Relativity that either introduce additional scalar/vector fields or introduce modifications in the high curvature regime. The PI will then study how well one can probe these theories through current and future multimessenger observations. To achieve the educational goal, the PI's team will develop an online game on General Relativity and gravitational waves to reach out to young players across the world. In the game instructions, the PI will provide a brief description of General Relativity, black holes, and gravitational waves, conveying the excitement and key aspects of recent Nobel-prize winning physics. Some students will be involved in the game development, integrating the research and educational activities. The PI will make the source codes publicly available so that anyone can develop their own games.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
“Exploring Strong-field Gravity through Gravitational-wave and Multimessenger Observations'' (PI: Kent Yagi) integrates a research program to reveal the extreme nature of gravity from gravitational wave observations with online game development to expose the public to frontier research fields in physics.

Intellectual Merit

The PI worked in three main directions, (i) towards constructing inspiral-merger-ringdown waveforms in theories beyond General Relativity (GR), (ii) carrying out various tests of gravity with gravitational waves, and (iii) testing gravity with universal relations for neutron stars.

Gravitational waves from a compact binary merger consist of inspiral, merger, and ringdown. The first and last phases can be computed analytically while the merger phase relies on numerical relativity simulations. In the first research direction, the PI and collaborators constructed new gravitational waveforms in GR that are valid in all of the inspiral-merger-ringdown but use only minimal information about the simulations. This formalism would be very useful in constructing inspiral-merger-ringdown waveforms in theories beyond GR as the number of available simulations is much fewer in such theories than in GR.

Regarding the second direction, the PI studied specific beyond-GR theories, such as those involving extra dimensions, and also worked on a model-independent framework. The PI and collaborators developed a method for computing energy carried away from gravitational waves that is necessary for constructing gravitational waveforms in extra dimension models. The PI and collaborators also constructed a parameterized spacetime for a spinning black hole that can capture non-GR effects in a theory-agnostic way and computed ringdown frequencies in such a spacetime.

Relations among certain observables of neutron stars are known to be insensitive to the unknown stellar internal structure. These relations are useful in probing gravitational physics with neutron star observations without being contaminated by uncertainties in nuclear physics. In the third research direction, the PI studied such universal relations in theories beyond GR that introduce a preferred direction in spacetime. Accounting for the existing bounds on the theories from various observations and experiments, the PI found that the relations remain universal even in such non-GR theories and the deviation from GR is negligible. This shows that it would be challenging to further constrain the theories with neutron star observations through these universal relations.

Broader Impact

The PI and his former student developed an online game “Gravitational Wave Surfer” using a real-time game development platform called Unity. A player is assumed to be a proton floating in space and is asked to form an atom (e.g. carbon with 6 protons, 6 neutrons, and 6 electrons) by collecting the right number of protons, neutrons, and electrons that are also floating in space. The player can move around inside the screen that is discretized in grids to indicate spacetime. Frequently, the player will see two black holes colliding and the size of each grid expands/shrinks to show the gravitational-wave passage. During this phase, particles will move around, making it difficult for the player to collect them. The game has an instruction at the beginning that explains not only how to play the game, but also teaches the player the concept of GR, black holes, and gravitational waves.
